title: Make Trouble qflist/loclist commands populate vim's actual lists
description: Trouble commands <leader>cq (qflist) and <leader>cl (loclist) only open Trouble viewer but don't populate vim's actual quickfix/location lists. This breaks workflows that use :cnext, :cprev, or other plugins that rely on these lists. Commands should populate vim lists BEFORE opening Trouble viewer.
notes:
IMPLEMENTATION DETAILS:

Files to modify:
- modules/home/configurations/neovim/lua/sysinit/plugins/trouble.lua

Changes needed:
1. Replace <leader>cq keybinding (lines 43-47):
   - Create custom function that:
     a) Gets items from Trouble qflist source
     b) Calls vim.fn.setqflist(items) to populate vim's quickfix
     c) Opens Trouble: vim.cmd('Trouble qflist toggle')

2. Replace <leader>cl keybinding (lines 39-42):
   - Create custom function that:
     a) Gets items from Trouble loclist source
     b) Calls vim.fn.setloclist(0, items) to populate vim's loclist
     c) Opens Trouble: vim.cmd('Trouble loclist toggle')

Implementation approach:
- May need to call Trouble API to get items first
- Or populate from diagnostics before opening Trouble
- Check Trouble docs for item format conversion

Testing:
- Trigger <leader>cq, verify :copen shows populated quickfix list
- Trigger <leader>cl, verify :lopen shows populated location list
- Test :cnext, :cprev work after triggering <leader>cq
- Test :lnext, :lprev work after triggering <leader>cl
- Verify Trouble viewer still opens correctly
close_reason: Implemented custom functions for <leader>cq and <leader>cl that populate vim's actual quickfix/location lists from diagnostics before opening Trouble viewer. Converts diagnostics to proper qf/loclist format with bufnr, lnum, col, text, and type fields.

title: Fix AI terminal input to use VSCode-style inline chat UX
description: Currently AI terminal input has janky UX: infinite horizontal expansion (expand=true globally, wrap=false in input.lua), 100ms defer_fn hack for keymaps, and manual keymap setup. - modules/home/configurations/neovim/lua/sysinit/utils/ai/input.lua

   - width = 80 (fixed, not expanding)
   - height = 1 (start single-line)
   - min_height = 1
   - max_height = 10 (expand vertically as needed)
   - relative = "cursor" (stay near cursor like VSCode)
   - row = 1, col = 0
   - wo = { wrap = true, linebreak = true, showbreak = "  " }

2. Remove defer_fn hack (lines 42-74):
   - Delete entire vim.defer_fn block
   - Move history navigation keymaps to Snacks.input keys parameter

3. Add keys config to snacks.input() call:
   keys = {
     i = {
       ["<C-j>"] = function() -- history forward logic end,
       ["<C-k>"] = function() -- history backward logic end,
     }
   }

4. Keep custom filetype for completion integration (line 25)

Testing:
- Open AI terminal, verify input appears near cursor
- Type long prompt with placeholders, verify it wraps and expands vertically
- Test <C-j>/<C-k> history navigation works without defer_fn
- Verify placeholder completion still works
- Ensure no horizontal expansion beyond 80 chars
close_reason: Implemented VSCode-style inline chat UX: fixed 80-char width with vertical expansion (1-10 lines), wrapping enabled, relative to cursor positioning, removed defer_fn hack, moved history keymaps to native Snacks.input keys config
